												Brothers in Arms: Hell's Highway was an amazing experience and an example on what modern military shooters should do nowadays, yes, looking at you, Call of Duty and Battlefield. At thing which bugs me about modern shooters is that every single one of them has its focus on the repetitive multiplayer where as today most of them play essentially the same, just as the campaign. We need more games like Hell's Highway which are not glorifying war but show the human side the soldiers have instead of how many times they can yell "♥♥♥♥ YEAH, AMERICA!" while pulling out the flamethrower to "burn them, burn them all!!!"The men you fight along in Hell's Highway feel human and just as in the older Brother's in Arms games, the main focus lies in the single player. If you want to buy this game for a killstreak loaded multi player to "pwn scrubs", you are wrong here.A roughly about 10 hours long campaign (I played on Veteran difficulty)  will keep you motivated with a nice tactical component to command different squads such as the MG squad or the assault team as Matthew Baker, to surpress the enemy and use the element of surprise to flank clueless and somtimes dumb acting enemy soldiers. The commanding barely gets old and as you hop around different hubs of the hot areas during the war. Those range from wide fields to close battles in troubled cities and villages as well as asylums and collapsed buildings.The thing which does get a little repetitive are the objectives you have to achieve using those methods of commanding. Most of the time you find yourself having to destroy 88 cannons and sometimes drive a tank around in which you are mostly safe even on the higher difficulties. Really annoying did those things only become in the end to me, as the game finally came to a closing, during the last hour of gameplay. The story itself kept motivating as protagonist Matthew Baker's mind started to crumble and he realized more and more and war is insanity. The "To Be Continued" in the end was a huge bummer to me though, especially because Ubisoft doesn't seem to care at all about this amazing series which could definetly standout amongst "Call of Boredom" or the recent development of the"Battlefail" games.It doesn't need amazing graphics to make a good game. While Brothers in Arms may looked fine back in the day it is quite outdated for the modern standards. Second to none facial animations, horrible lip-synching at times but nice destructability of cover and physical correctness of the debris look damn fine as well as gore and ragdoll of fallen enemy soldiers. Also the sound design is great and as the bullets fly over your head  in cover and the enemies speaking correct German, which is a rare thing to see to be honest. The atmosphere is really great and makes you feel as if this was an episode of the critically acclaimed "Band of Brothers"-TV show. The developers really did a great job in capturing an unique and equally terrifying experience.Overall Brothers in Arms: Hell's Highway is a technically and gameplay wise far from flawless but also an unique and tactical game which definetly gets a recommendation for me, even if solely for the atmosphere and the long campaign.Grab this game if you are sick of modern shooters and/or glorification of war.

 "I never asked to be a squad leader, but I had no choice." - Sergeant Matthew 'Matt' Baker Side noteI abused the summer sale to finaly purchase the Brothers In Arms Series over Steam as I already own the DVD versions of it. I did it in order to review it for you guys, not to mention the fact I am tired of the discs. This series is the most authentic World War 2 video game you can find in the video games market. Unlike any other kinds of games, you are really leading your men during battles and their faith in the battlefield is in your hands.Now, to the point, Brothers In Arms: Hell's Highway review.IntroductionIn Brothers In Arms: Hell's Highway you are playing as Staff Sergeant Matthew Baker also known as Matt. You are leading your men through Holland during Operation Market Garden, an Operation that had the idea of punching through the German lines in order to open a highway to give a quick end to the war and be home by Christmass.After Normandy (First 2 BiA games), Baker's platoon is folded into a brand new Reconnaissance platoon. The recon platoon relies on their jeeps for fast movement through the battlefields to recon and harass enemy positions. The squad is broken up to two teams assigned into jeeps.GameplayMovement - Movement animations are great and realistic. Whether you are walking, running or getting behind cover it feels like you are really in the battlefield. - GOODEngaging An Enemy - Your squad has two modes of engagement. If the Squad is in stealth mod, which means the enemy didn't notice them - They would move quietly and whisper and would not engage the enemyunless you order them to or the enemy has opened fire at them. The other mod is if they are seen and they are during a battle they will open fire at engaging enemies even if you won't order them to. - GOODGrenades - Your squad will throw grenades at an enemy if they are close enough. But the enemy will never throw a grenade at your squad, even tho they are equipped with grenades. - BADRecoil - The recoil of the weapons in the game is as realistic as it gets with most weapons. Just enough to keep the game enjoyable but still making your life hard to get a kill on enemy that is far away from you. - GOODTanks and 88s - Feels like the enemy tanks and 88s are just waiting for you to destroy them. No huge effort is in order to destory them. I didn't like it. - BADSounds - The game has awesome sounds when it comes to the weapons and the area that sorrounds you. - GOODDestroy Em! - Plus, unlike the first two games, in this game you can actually destroy objects. For example you can destroy sorts of covers and get your enemy out in the open and kill them.StorylineUnlike the first two games, this game has taken the cutscenes to the next level. Almost feels like you are watching a movie and you are the lead actor.The game has great writing. The cutscenes are adding alot to the game and to the emotions you feel while playing it. Almost feels like you are there and not Baker.The dialouges during Battles are amusing and it feels real. Unlike in other games where when your teammates die you don't feel anything because they were 'Badass', here you are connected to the chararcters emotionaly, you care for them and you are conecered about them during battles. When a fellow team mate gets killed, it feels like someone has just kicked you in the stomach and it brings up feelings, almost to tears at some points. In addition to what I said, in this game Baker suffers from guilt as a result of the deaths of his friends during the battles in Normandy and you can see its affect on him through out the game. The locations of fights in the game are re-created real battles that took place in the real world, they were worked on by the developers team and historians to make the game more authentic and realistic.  GraphicsThe game has amazing graphics. The areas that sorround you in the game are just beautiful and mind blowing at the same time. The uniforms of the Allied and of the Wermacht are just beautiful to look at, the weapons look way more authentic and more. There are beautiful locations in alot of occassions in the game.My OpinionIn my opinion the Brothers In Arms Series is the best World War 2 series to exist. Its the most authentic world war 2 series and most realstic. It has great gameplay and storyline and bringsalot of features that other games don't. No other game made me care for my team like Brothers In Arms did. I replayed every and each one of the games for so many times, I just can't get enough of it.I am still waiting for Brothers In Arms: Battle Of The Bulge, or what ever the name of the next Brothers In Arms is going to be. The Brothers In Arms Series needs to have a closure.I suggest to you to buy the game, but also consider playing the first 2 games first to get a better idea of whats going on with Baker in this game and understand the game more deeply. Tips for gameplay:  1)Play the game without supression bars or any other kind of miscs on your screen;While playing with a clean screen you can enjoy the game way more than you thought you could.Playing with a clean screen gives you the feeling you are really there in the battlefield, ordering your men.*You will need to remember where you placed each squad and what's the role of each firing team when you order them to move because it won't tell you which firing team you chose on the screen. You might wanna know who are the soldiers of each team before you order them around so in the battlefield you will remember by that which squad is located where and move them around correctly.*You will need to keep an eye on your fire, yeah I know hammering the enemy is fun but when you don't know how much bullets you have left in the magazine or if you have extra bullets if at all you might run into some trouble in a battle - yeah running out of bullets infornt of a german firing squad is not a great idea nor fun.2) Play the game on authentic. Playing the Brothers In Arms series on Authentic gives you the real feeling of the battlefield. It gives you the best out of this game. Every small move, decision or order can be critical in a battle. It also disables all I said above(miscs, etc) on default because of the extact same reasons I pointed out earlier. You need to be super strategic and careful when you move your men and yourself. Stay in the open for to long and you might find yourself dead, injured or losing men. Thanks for reading my review.

												It's a good game - a strong example of a squad-based shooter. You control the position and focus of 1-3 fireteams, edging your way through battlefields to flank enemies and progress through linear levels. It encourages you to leverage your fireteams because your own weapons are unreliable to the extreme - on par with Counter-strike accuracy. Bullets spray for no particular reason, shots that are dead-on don't always register, and enemies take many shots to take down. While that's frustrating, it highlights that you are not a pure badass. Sure you may mow down hundreds of enemies in a playthrough, but ultimately it tries to knock you down to size with it's iffy gun mechanics - you need to use your squad to succeed. And while it is frustrating to not be rewarded for your own skill, i can understand that sloppy controls make you rely on your squad more.It also seems to want to be Band of Brothers, the TV show. The game spends an enormous amount of time showing wooden characters (some of which are obviously derived from Band of Brothers characters, one of which even shares a voice actor) talking to each other about the war and each other. It spins narratives about cursed guns and lost loves which have exactly nothing to do with the game. The first ten minutes (not an exaggeration) is a series of unskippable cutscenes that awkwardly introduce a set of characters which it clearly wants you to be invested in. It keeps introducing new characters who have small quirks and different voice actors, but whom you really don't care about. When it kills off or maims a character, you're clearly expected to care, but there's no *reason* to care; the gameplay (controlling the position and focus of 1-3 fireteams) is identical no matter which characters are involved, and you're aways given replacements who are exactly as capable. Cutscene after cutscene is used, even with "shaky-cam" effects and close-ups of expressionless faces. It's all the more frustrating because this came out a year after Bioshock, a game which is almost purely story-driven, uses the same engine, and yet falls into none of the gameplay or storytelling pitfalls that this game does.Ultimately, it's a fun game that executes a squad shooter very well, despite the flaws. I'd recommend it if you're certain you want a squad shooter, and wouldn't recommend it for any other reason.

Get ready for a trip to the past, with one of the most immersive, well-created, tactical FPS in the history of video-games. This is one HELL of a game. It follows the men of the 101st Airborne Division in the later stages of World War 2, during Operation Market Garden, in the Netherlands. Unfortunately, this is the last installment in the series, at least for now, but we still hope that Ubisoft will give us another Brothers In Arms, with current gen graphics.The graphics are very good for a game from 2008. The gore is amazing, you'll see body parts flying around, and depending on the weapon you're using, it might dismember the enemies or not. Keep in mind, before you buy, this is NOT a typical run and shoot game. It does involve strategy and thinking, so if you think that running around on the battlefield will solve it, you're better off not playing it, because you'll die within seconds. 												A masterpiece. Really, there is not a thing I do not like about Hell's Highway. Well, actually, there is one: The story won't continue and that's something I just can't get over. But let's be professional here.This is one hell of a fantastic shooter. You continue in the story of Sgt. Matt Baker a paratrooper of 101st Airborne Division. He and his men have already gone through hell in Normandy and now there is another one ahead of them: Operation Market Garden.Gameplay is fantastic, controls are easy to learn and handle. 3rd person view, utilizing a cover and issuing orders for squads under your command. Game will quickly teach you how to use tactical manouvering and suppresive fire. Forget Call of Duty, you are no supersoldier who can take out whole garrison single-handed. No. You need to rain lead down on your enemy, so they won't dare to stick their heads up. Once they are pinned, you can outflank them and finnish from the side. Especially on higher difficuilties, the game require you to think tactically. That's what I like most.Story is one of best I ever encountered. Characters are unique, while still remain ordinary troops. No stereotypes like e.g. psycho gunner, excellent sharpshooter, and demolition guy. No, no. Brothers in Arms is all about grunts, ordinary soldiers. It's about their feels, their stories. Many of your soldiers have their own backstory (sometimes linked to previeous installments in the series), they have a different level of relationship with Sgt. Baker. Some would go to fire for him, others are questioning his ability to lead them. New guys who want to prove themselves, old friends, loyal to the end. Each with great voice-acting. Warning: there will be emotions. Thanks to excellent animation of facial expressions, you can read thoughts of your men to the point, where you will truly be part of the story. You will mourn the fallen comrade, you will mourn dead civilians. Their blood will be on your hands and altough there are no choices in this game, you will feel responsible for some of your actions nonetheless. Story is something, which make this game a real gem of WWII shooters.And here we are - the thing I don't like. After Market Garden, there was yet another hell awaiting for paratroopers of 101st and 82nd Airborne Division. The snowy, freezing hell of Ardenne forest. Yes, Battle of the Bulge, it was supposed to be a cap stone of the story of Matt Baker and his soldiers. In the end of Hell's Highway, there is a rift, there are emotions and there are questions unanswered. I want to know how will it all end. After all, Matt made it through hell. I wonder how he would handle snow. But game devolopers will never answer my prayers...Anyway, this is a game I recommend to any and all who like historicaly acurate WWII shooters, who like great story and who like to think tactically and feel the war as a soldier, not some god-like spec op superman.

												A refreshingly relatable and grounded take on war in videos games. Relying more on character and personal moments than big overly produced set pieces. That's not to say the actual action isn't great, it's full of the same nitty gritty combat of any other solidly crafted war shooter. But it's not what makes Hell's Highway stand out, it's the smaller details that do. The tension of combat and planing out your battles, the humanity and development given to your comrades, the atmospheric levels full of booming sounds of the battlefield and eerie silence of empty village streets and farms. Many games capture the sheer power and brutality of war. But only a small handful capture the real warriors themselves. The thoughts and feelings of men forced to fight and die in a cause they may not fully understand nor sometimes even fully care about. Hell's Highway is one of those rare games that does.

Posted: January 4
												Hell's Highway feels a full generation away from it's predecessors - the graphics are vastly improved and the tech can finally tell the story with all the drama and tension that they've been aiming for since the beginning. It also feels like a new generation in terms of the fact that a lot of the gameplay has been streamlined (grenade throwing has been tightened up, thank god), and, in my opinion, these changes have made the game easier. The new appearance of OP weapons like the bazooka team and the player-controlled tank make it a cakewalk to mop up whole squads of enemies in one shot. Your Thompson is also replaced early on with a barrel-cartridge tommy gun that feels like it never runs out of ammo. You can, with relative ease, stand back and pick off enemies from afar with the new cover system that allows you to peek around corners and focus your fire, and if you do happen to flank the enemy, often they'll stand straight up and into your squadmates' gunfire, dying in seconds. All these additions detract from the immersion, and make the game feel a little more arcadey, even thought the core gamplay mechanics are nearly identical to the previous games. All in all, this game feels much more polished and fancy, but loses some of the pulse-pounding, gritty tension of knowing that even if you're prepared, bum-rushing that dug-in squad could get you killed.The one thing this does best is make you feel. By the last levels of the game, you'll almost want to stop playing, and the push through burning wreckages and sand dunes, being harried by multiple enemy squads, will feel dreadful, but you know that you have to keep pushing through in order to complete the mission, which is exactly how the characters feel. The narrative continues the story of Matt Baker, who is experiencing some deep PTSD/mental illness. It's incredibly bleak all the way through, and centres around a specific and almost rushed-through moment in the original game, which is retroactively filled out to fantastic effect for the player, explaining the actions of some of the characters all the way through the series. There is a subplot about a cursed weapon that it also tries to retrofit, but this doesn't stick quite as well. So that's it - I've played all three games in the series, one after the other, in the space of a couple of weeks. This used to be my preferred game, and it's the one I've played most, but after playing them back to back, Earned in Blood is easily my favourite, and balances a quality narrative, with realistic and rewarding gameplay, a battlefield that sounds truly alive, memorable level design, and just the right level of difficulty that rewards good tactics. The original game falls on the side of being a little too clunky, and this falls on the side of being a little too streamlined, for my tastes. In saying that, because the narrative intertwines throughout the three games, you really must play all three in order to get the full effect. Clever move, Gearbox.I recommend this more than RTH30, but less than EiB.

												A worthy sequel to the first two Brothers in Arms games. There's a very emotional story here that makes the events of the previous games come full circle, and one which the game flaunts with well choreographed cinematics. The gameplay feels like a next-gen evolution of Brothers in Arms in all the right ways. Cover, destructible levels, multi-squad command, air recon, the map replacing SA view, sprinting, and the kill-cam all fit right into Brothers in Arms and don't make the game lose its identity at all. The levels are bigger and better than anything seen before, and the enemy AI is as great as it ever was. The graphics, unlike the first two BiA games, actually stand the test of time thanks to vibrant, colorful levels and tasteful use of visual effects and bump mapping, unlike most early 7th gen video games. There are a few bugs, but not enough to ruin the experience. What does ruin the experience for players experiencing the game on Veteran is the fact that the player cannot use iron sights directly out of cover, which makes cover useless when the crosshair is disabled. Another issue is that weapon sway when aiming is not in this game, except for a second immediately after the player aims. Other than that, this game is an improvement over the originals in every way.WARNING: IF YOU DO NOT DISABLE SLI BEFORE YOU PLAY THIS GAME, YOU WILL GET UNPLAYABLE AMOUNTS OF LAG!!

Posted: January 1, 2014
												Hell's Highway is a game with a solid gameplay experience, an interesting narrative, and some glaring faults.As a direct sequel to the first game in the Brothers in Arms series Hell's Highway follows newly-promoted Staff Sergeant Matt Baker and his unit  through the Netherlands during Operation Market Garden. Baker's sanity wanes due to the contention of his men, rumors of a haunted pistol, and the memories of friends lost. The combat in HH holds to the tradition of the earlier titles in the series, while adding additional squads and features. Flanking and diversionary tactics are vital, as running into the open while an enemy fires upon Baker or his squad will result in a quick death.However, Hell's Highway is a game that needs some fixing to enjoy. For anyone like myself who gets headaches or feels sick at a lower field of view, here's different methods of how to counter the horrid default setting.--------------Method 1: A simple binding to toggle the fov. This will change the fov when pressed, but will zoom out cutscenes, break sniper scopes, and disable zooming in when aiming.Go to your "Documents\My Games\BIA Hells Highway\SumacGame\Config" folder and open "SumacInput.ini" in a text editor. under the"[Engine.PlayerInput]" section add the following.Bindings=(Name="KEY",Command="fov DESIREDFOV",Control=False,Shift=False,Alt=False)Method 2: Changing the action of the zoom hold command to change the fov. The fov will lower when aiming to zoom in, then zoom out to your desired standard fov on release. This will also zoom out cutscenes and break sniper scopes. I suggest a zoom fov of 60, and a standard fov of 100.Under "[Engine.InputActionDefinition]" in SumacInput.ini look for the line that starts with "Actions=(Id=IA_ZoomHold,Alias...".Change the line to, "Actions=(Id=IA_ZoomHold,Alias=".ZOOMHOLD",Names=("Zoom"),Command="ZoomIn | fov DESIREDZOOMFOV | OnRelease ZoomOut | OnRelease DESIRED DEFAULT FOV")"Other tips:Creating a bind similar to the bind shown in method 1 set to "fov 63" will set cutscenes close to what they look like normally.In the "[SystemSettings]" section of "SumacEngine.ini" you can pump up the graphics. I suggest setting "EnableHighPolyChars=False" to "True" and fiddling around with the MSAA.-------------Like Far Cry 2, Syndicate, and Rage a good game is held back by stupid issues that can be solved with a few simple tweaks. I enjoy fixing issues in PC ports, so I may be biased, but Hell's Highway is one of my favorite games of the last eight years.

Posted: March 30, 2016
												I was in the mood for a world war 2 shooter, since nowadays those are surprisingly rare. I read reviews on Steam and Metacritic to see what was popular and Hell's Highway came up.After beating the game I am still not entirely sure if the game deserves a recommendation or not.For starters, the game has some glaring errors in historical accuracy, such as German 88's firing at Sherman tanks at point blank range and failing to penetrate or a single such Sherman tank rolling through hundreds of men, tanks and 88's (for some reason there are no other antitank guns in this game, just the 88 anti-air -guns) with ease. The graphics (originally designed for the Xbox 360) are obviously dated, with character models warping and distorting uncomfortably and facial animation all but missing entirely. The voice acting is lackluster to say the least, ambients sounds are often missing, weapons sound muted and dull and even the music seems to be oddly off-key in few points (though this part might just be my lack of knowledge showing through). All in all, the game's audiovisual presentation is pretty terrible. Even the ragdoll physics are glitchy as heck (I shot a german soldier in the head and he jumped 50 meters in the air as he died)!So far, then, this seems like a no-brainer: an ugly game with bad audiovisual design through and through.And then we get to the gameplay, and here I find myself intrigued. You are acting as a squad leader for most of the game, and that means you cannot just charge the enemy Call of Duty -style, but have to order around your fireteams (up to three at a time, ranging from machine gun team to base of fire team to bazooka team to assault team), setting them up in cover, assigning them targets to suppress and maneuvering them to outflank the enemy. The levels offer a sometimes surprising amount of freedom in how much you can maneuver and the system feels surprisingly good most of the time. I especially enjoyed the frantic tension of emerging into a new area only to observe a german squad marching across a field, ordering my men into position and then watching the enemy spread out into cover as the shooting starts. The enemy AI is also surprisingly good, acting surprised where appropriate, falling back and regrouping into better positions as they are overrun our outflanked and generally putting up a good fight.And then the game shoots itself in the foot again. Several times I had the AI completely glitch out, with my machinegun team or bazooka team simply freezing in place and refusing to move, getting stuck in walls or cover and such. The game hands you a sniper rifle on a few occasions, which immediately results in you, single handedly, gunning down literally dozens of germans within a minute or two, utterly breaking any immersion the game might have had so far. The tone of the game is all over the place, and then, in the end credits, comes the final straw. The story ends on a minor cliffhanger with "To Be Continued" -emblazoned on the screen. This game came out in 2008. I played it in 2016. There are no sequels, and likely never will be.Game Over.Playtime: 8+ hours (single playthrough)Ratings (1-10)Visual: 5Audio: 5Story: 7Gameplay: 8Overall: 7

												Played the two before this... played the first episode of this game and here's the thing:Road to Hill 30Earned in blood- You could set up the controls for these games for your controller easily using a software like joy2key- Now, unless you have the PS4 v2 controller (which I have or some high varient) but not PS3 or, PS4 v1 (latter due to bluetooth only) - you can not set your controller because they've given controls for you that are completely awful and bare no resemblence to more common controls such as Call of Duty - with the DS4 however you can change this but I must have spent atleast 15 minutes pulling me out of the game.- Aiming, most of the time you're going to find yourself wanting to be in cover, unlike the previous within the franchise - you can no longer aiming down a scope behind cover, there's no crouch button so must rely on the 3rd person, you get the unrealistic feel that Band Of Brother's had the franchise of almost giving you a full realism - atleast closer than any other WW2.- Another notable aspect of Band of Brothers - NO HEALTH REVIVE, which really did make the game glorious, it gave you a reason to play as you would in warfare, okay - if you messed up bad, you get the option to gain a full health and ammo restock if you died 3 times at a point which you didn't have to take and they emphasised the principle that "wars not fair but games shouldn't have to be" giving you that serious outlook... it's to be respected if you like these kind of games. What they've done in this game of-course is make it easy giving you a revive. :/- Easy, easy, easy - I can't go on authentic mode, so I'm stuck on veteran - but I find myself running into a room with 2 germans shooting me with mp40s... I had my thompson and took care of them when they both got the first shot - FAR FROM THE ORIGINAL GAME, you had to 1 option in the first game - flank, in the second game two options - flank or pray you hit while you peak out of cover for a moment because they made flanking harder (you had to take off maybe 1 guy in a group before trying to flank). This is it's just like meh, (to crew) come along guys... "zzzzzzzzz" oh I left you behind "waits for them to catch up" because they serve no real use in this game - they're meant to draw fire away from you.- Completely hate how they removed features of the old game and threw in new ones in a clunky way - when I order my team to attack, it's instant for them whereas for me it's proper clunky, I can't use the button to aim while I'm in cover but have to move the analogue up? "Wrong".- There seems to be no way to cancel your command either WHICH IS A MASSIVE NO... if you're going to tell you're team to shoot someone and they die - you need to cancel your command or you end up having you angle your camera at them "while getting shot" to direct them where they already are... This game doesn't let you see the controls at all on a screen. I still can't believe there are people who make games who don't allow you to set up controls to the way you like - that needs to die. If there is a way to cancel command they're hiding it pretty well.- Enemies can be shot behind cover so easily they shouldn't call this "Brothers In Arms"... You basically depended on open shots only... vise versa for the enemy except at the later game - you could still hit but you're always at a major risk of getting shot if the enemy lines up on you. YOU HAD TO BE PATIENT AND IT WAS WORTH THE REWARD - YOU BECOME A TOP PLAYER. THIS FRANCHISE TRAINED ME IN MANY OTHER GAMES - completely lost the ability to role through that here and reading the other comments they all say it's about the same the whole way through.What band of brothers should have done:Made the AI smarter and not dumber trying to appeal to the "easy crowd"... If the AI realises they're being flanked/in a cross fire... they try to pull back to where you'd progress in the game and situate with the next german's - you see this in earned in blood adding a challenge to get the enemy before they seek cover but this only really applied to MG42, 88mm users and Anti-tank gun users. AI could also try to look for better cover. What I see now - "ohh we caught them by suprise, yeah they're just going to trapes this way knowing that Allies are in the area by the captain obvious plans in the sky dropping troops"... I couldn't take any of that for real.Allow you a slight choice of weapons at the start - obviously you don't want the list or you'd always pick the sniper rifle - but like - do you want "M1 Garand or M1 Carbine", do you want "The thompson or the Bar", do you want "The pistol or 1 a law with 2 rounds"? which would make it great if the game was good enough for a second play through (ie; for authentic).The odd enemy grenade drop would be nice.I wasn't a fan of the "no ammo restockable for US weapons" in Road to hill 30 nor the "infinite ammo from team" in earned in blood... It should have come down to - ammo is scarse in the game but if you found a random/rare dead US soldier - you could take the ammo, or a random drive-by soldier in a jeep handing out ammo along the way... - 1 flare that will mark a supply drop some point in the game where you can refill "infinitely but the crate will stay there"The lack of a melee button despite you never needed it apart from that 1 very rare time you killed 2 enemies with your thompson and that last one is really injured trying to reload his K-98 it would be quicker to hit him that reload yourself (vise versa).SPOILER FOR "Earned in blood" below (then again, I'm guessing people have played it or won't bother playing it if they're here)Baker vs Red - they killed the story when they gave away the twist at the beginning - stopping people from wanting to play and heck - doesn't an ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ like Red normally die in these stories? The judgemental got at the person who succeeds rather than who promoted them (despite baker seemed to have a much harder time getting the tanks ALONE vs Red who had 6 guys with him on road 30 which was an absolutely terrible decision Hill 30 should have been over-run with 2 people defending the trench) That poor judgement in and of itself is meant to say "this character is going to die and there will be a heartwarming moment at the end where he realises baker got him wrong". - That whole idea may seem corny, but it reflects real life which is what the game was trying to aim at to begin with (till this one), whatever your taste, baker easily getting mowed down was far from what Baker really way.So yeah, I honestly wanted to like it, but this is just going to be difficult to finish - if I have the time, when I have other games I can play... so yeah. 5.5/10 since it's not a realistic game (lost it's category) and it barely performs like a mainstream game like it basically sells itself as. 												I just do not like this franchise at all. Hell’s highway’s story is competent and in my opinion it is the best story in the franchise but that’s not saying much. I did like the increase in production value, it’s nothing impressive but it gets the job done and the presentation overall is much better than the previous two. They added a very bland cover system and regenerating health. The shots you take from cover are on point now so you never have to use your squad because you are a one man army, even on the higher difficulties. Peek from cover, kill about 2 enemies with headshots then get back into cover and regen your health, that’s the game in a nutshell. This honestly would have been fine though if the shooting was actually satisfying but it’s just not. In the first two games they made the gameplay so you couldn’t hit anything with your gun so the game forced you to use your squad to help take out the enemies. In this game you see all the enemies with the third person cover and you are practically a sniper when you peek out from cover killing anything In your way so your squad is practically useless. This game is just a very bad experience and it’s a very boring one too. The decent story and budget increase is pretty much the only redeeming qualities of this game. 3/10 (Bad)

Things will be happening and there are either no sounds for them or the sounds are not correct or are so off.Shooting dousn't feel great and feels pretty vanilla if that makes sense, the voice actors are pretty terrible but atleast they have a real sound crew doing the tech work in this one (unlike the first game where it wasn't unheard of to have VO redline/sound awfull). But they still sound like crap because the actors suck. Story can be pretty confusing and fragmented in weird ways aswell. Its basically a cheap bargain bin WW2 game that. Thats BIA. I feel like for the BIA games they just copied mechanics of other better games and especially when they were popular. When Socom/Freedom Fighters and COD were popular they made the first two games, when Gears of War and shoulder high walls became popular they put that into the game. But honestly the cover mechanics make this game better, one of the issues in earlier games was that you couldn't go third person and get a feel for whats going on very quickly, so you could either look at a wall then pop out or risk being shot and just stand there.The damage system is ♥♥♥♥ing terrible. I don't think you need to get shot to get hurt, but its so terrible I can't describe it. You regen health though but its not like that makes it better. You have to hit the enemies and work to get shots to hit their mark but they can just spray all over the place and still hit you.AI is terrible, especially friendly AI. They either path in the way of fire or they decide to run around like headless chickens even though you gave the order to stay where they were. Its about on level with Road to Hill 30 give or take.I would say the game as a whole objectively and as a game is better than Road to Hill 30. Its atleast easy to shoot people once you learn the system, and its otherwise given a bit more polish. Unfortunately its still not a polished game and is only a bit better in general than the older ones but its that extra bit that makes it a playable and enjoyable video game. BIA is a bargain bin series, which is unfortunate as there are points that you can see a gleam of something great shine through in production or writing, but then it falls apart when a character is looking at you with a look that makes you think hes holding back maniacal laughter right after a character died.  Its this kind of stuff that makes it impossible to care about anything in this game aside from the base combat. Also your squad can die, but they respawn at the next check point, which also makes you not give a♥♥♥♥♥♥about characters since they die over and over and over until they die in the story. They also tried some weird F.E.A.R. like situations where its supposed to be spooky but its just stupid and the enemy AI and gun play show themselves as terrible when compared to FEAR (which is one of the best FPS in terms of gunplay and especially AI). Man,  I don't recommend this game, but if you want to play a BIA game this is the one you ought to. Its still pretty below average though but its not as terrible as the older ones.If they remade the games they could easily make them great though. Add some more polish and make the existing systems make logical sense. It wouldn't take a terribly large amount of work to make Hill 30 into a great game but it would take money. Which is fairly obvious with these games they didn't want to spend money, they wanted to put out something quick that would make a profit off current trends then move on.For what its worth I kinda like it. Not enough games let you command units whilst directly controlling your own character. But its certaintly not a objectively and mechanicly good game. Its okay at best.
